title: reference request - Not exactly directed percolation
body: Is the following problem known/well-studies? I'm looking for references or a name that I can look up. I start with $N$ cell, each one divides into two cells, each one of the new cells either dies with probability $p$ or divides into two cells, and so on. What is the probability distribution of the number of cells after $n$ generations? What can be said about the critical $p$ below which the population goes extinct? Are there Universal scaling laws for this extinction transition? At first, I thought it was directed percolation problem , but the exponential growth in the possible number of cells is not consistent with DP. reference-request pr.probability random-graphs statistical-physics percolation Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked Jan 25, 2018 at 1:45 stochastic 371 1 1 silver badge 11 11 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 6 $\begingroup$ I would say that this is $N$ independent Galton–Watson processes, where the distribution of the r.v. are concentrated on 0 and 2. $\endgroup$ Leandro –  Leandro 2018-01-25 02:25:03 +00:00 Commented Jan 25, 2018 at 2:25 $\begingroup$ @Leandro Thank you, that is exactly what I needed to know $\endgroup$ stochastic –  stochastic 2018-01-25 06:23:23 +00:00 Commented Jan 25, 2018 at 6:23 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
